section.title: <i>in case
section.sectiontitle: We can use in case to talk about past situations, to explain why somebody did something.
section.text1: We thought there might be long queues at the airport so we left early.
section.text1a: We left early in case there were long queues at the airport.
section.sectiontitle2: When talking about the past, the verb that follows in case can be Past Simple or Past Perfect.
section.text3a: We took our swimsuits in case there was a pool.
section.text4a: I phoned her again in case she hadn't heard the phone the first time.

section.title: <i>in case
section.sectiontitle: We can also use in case to talk about future situations, to talk about precautions.
section.text1a: You should insure your bicycle in case someone steals it.
section.text2a: Leave your mobile turned on in case I need to contact you.
section.sectiontitle2: When talking about the future, the verb that follows in case is normally in the present. We can use the present, future or a modal verb in the other clause.
section.text3a: I'll get plenty of food in case they're hungry.
section.text4a: You should take £50 with you in case the ticket costs more than you think.

section.title: <i>in case
section.sectiontitle: We can use just in case at the end of a sentence to talk about precautions in general (rather than specific situations).
section.text1a: I'll take some extra money with me just in case.
section.text2a: You'd better take some warm clothes, just in case.
section.sectiontitle2: We can use just in case to make in case a little more emphatic.
section.text3a: I'm going to apologise again just in case she's still angry with me.
section.text4a: I'll go and have a look just in case I've left something behind.
